rows.S41: PROBLEM DOCUMENT: The problems the coordination artifact (Trade) is designed to solve. This IS the research motivation.
Source: Vicioso Problems & Solutions tab (68 problems, 10 categories) + IonWave-specific additions
WHY THIS TAB EXISTS IN THE RESEARCH PAPER
The white paper claims the Trade replaces centralized management. These are the specific problems it claims to solve.
Every design decision in the Trade traces to one of these problems. If a feature doesn't solve a problem, delete it.
For researchers: this is the complete problem space. The Trade architecture is our proposed solution.

rows.col_2: Problem
rows.col_3: Why It Matters
rows.col_4: Trade Solution

rows.col_2: Company creation is artisanal — can't hire someone to finish/execute
rows.col_3: Can't scale, can't delegate, everything depends on one person
rows.col_4: Standardize into TUPs with tab structure, definitions, grading — anyone can execute from the artifact alone

rows.col_2: Solution must be cheap and easy — no elaborate enterprise systems
rows.col_3: Complex solutions won't be maintained or adopted
rows.col_4: Spreadsheet + templates + AI co-pilot = entire system, no custom software

rows.col_2: Unclear what's AI frontier vs organizational complexity
rows.col_3: Might be solving wrong problems or using wrong tools
rows.col_4: Human-in-the-loop design; AI co-pilot augments, doesn't replace

rows.col_2: Each TUP has dependencies to other TUPs — can't edit in isolation
rows.col_3: Change in one place breaks another
rows.col_4: Cross-TUP Dependencies tab traces flows; librarian maintains integrity

rows.col_2: Working memory overflow — 103 TUPs exceed human capacity
rows.col_3: Can't see the whole system, miss connections
rows.col_4: Cluster structure groups related TUPs; conductor sequences production

rows.col_2: Attention fragmentation — constant context-switching destroys flow
rows.col_3: Lose train of thought, miss connections
rows.col_4: Flash sprints: one cluster at a time, 2-3 week focus

rows.col_2: Tabs not completed — placeholders, empty columns, missing logic
rows.col_3: Work never finishes, quality varies
rows.col_4: Expert grading with cumulative TUP grade — nothing locks below B

rows.col_2: No shared vocabulary — terms mean different things across TUPs
rows.col_3: Miscommunication compounds into failures
rows.col_4: Conceptual Index with 500-700 word definitions for every key term

rows.col_2: 100 rounds of feedback until something is right
rows.col_3: Time and cost blow up, fatigue sets in
rows.col_4: Templates encode learning — AI starts at round 95, not round 1

rows.col_2: Lost context between sessions — reasoning and decisions disappear
rows.col_3: Repeat same mistakes, rediscover same insights
rows.col_4: Artifact IS the context. Librarian routes. MC produces the live show — the unfolding story of the Trade being built becomes the content itself.

rows.col_2: Knowledge stays in one person's head
rows.col_3: Bus factor = 1, scale impossible
rows.col_4: Lesson from PM A → template → PM B uses without founder

rows.col_2: Spreadsheet not easy for human to read vs narrative
rows.col_3: Can't understand WHY or HOW from rows
rows.col_4: MC produces a live show — the unfolding story of the company being born. Every conversation is an episode. Recruiting calls, expert reviews, daily updates, investor pitches — it's all one continuous documentary happening in real time. The show makes the artifact legible and the process visible.

rows.col_2: Founder is the bottleneck for execution
rows.col_3: Can't scale, burnout, single point of failure
rows.col_4: Flash teams execute from artifact; founder sets initial conditions only

rows.col_2: System can't run without founder for 30 days
rows.col_3: No vacation, no leverage
rows.col_4: THIS IS THE CORE RESEARCH QUESTION — can the artifact replace the founder?

rows.col_2: Don't have someone to manage contributors
rows.col_3: Founder becomes bottleneck for all decisions
rows.col_4: Artifact manages: templates + grading rubric + verification items = self-managing

rows.col_2: Not actually aligned when they start — 'complete' differs between people
rows.col_3: Misalignment discovered too late
rows.col_4: TUP structure defines exactly what 'complete' means; ACP grading provides objective criteria

rows.col_2: Async communication overhead — questions add days/weeks to timeline
rows.col_3: 2-week sprint becomes 6 weeks
rows.col_4: AI co-pilot answers most questions; librarian routes the rest; zero meetings

rows.col_2: Can't coordinate 40-60 strangers without meetings
rows.col_3: Traditional management doesn't scale to flash teams
rows.col_4: Coordination artifact replaces meetings — all info in the tabs, AI co-pilot provides context

rows.col_2: No way to grade distributed work consistently
rows.col_3: Quality varies wildly without centralized review
rows.col_4: Multi-grader system: AI (advisory) → Librarian (structural) → Expert (substance)

rows.col_2: Imagination and implementation feel disconnected from individual TUPs
rows.col_3: Contributors don't know where their work fits in the lifecycle
rows.col_4: TUP Lifecycle Phases — every TUP has explicit phase, every phase has explicit gate

rows.col_2: One-time infrastructure tasks (bank account, entity, 1Password) fall through cracks
rows.col_3: Blocking dependencies not tracked because they don't belong to any TUP
rows.col_4: Cross-TUP Dependencies tab with dedicated one-time system tasks section

rows.S41: PROBLEM DOCUMENT: TOTAL: 21 problems mapped (from 68 in Vicioso model + 4 IonWave-specific).
The full Vicioso problem set (68 problems, 10 categories) provides the theoretical grounding.
IonWave is the test case. If the Trade solves these 21 problems in practice, Paper 2 has its results.
FULL PROBLEM SET: See Origin Problems tab (65 problems, 9 categories) for the complete problem taxonomy.
Vicioso source: vicioso_full__3_.xlsx → Problems & Solutions tab (68 problems, institutional framing)
